name: wobbler
content:
wobbler noun [C]
(UNCERTAIN)
Add to word list
Add to word list
usually disapproving a person who is uncertain what to do or who changes repeatedly between two opinions: They were accused of being "will-they-won't-they" wobblers.
More examplesFewer examplesEven peaceniks, wobblers and appeasers accept that it will be necessary to use some form of force.In St Louis, at the very heart of Middle America, no one wanted to be exposed as a "wobbler" on the war.

wobbler noun [C]
(MOVING)
mainly UK a person or thing that is shaking, or that moves from side to side in a way that shows poor balance: She accused her brother of being a big obese wobbler. I wished I'd been sensible and worn my flat shoes, not my stiletto wobblers.
More examplesFewer examplesMany people were obese and most of the bodies on show were wobblers.He spied an opportunity and sent a low-flying wobbler of a kick inches over the bar.

wobbler noun [C]
(CRIME)
US a crime that can be charged in a court of law as being either less or more serious: In some states, certain crimes are described as "wobblers," which means that they may be charged as either a misdemeanor (punishable by less than a year's jail time) or a felony (punishable by a year or more). a wobbler offense/crime
More examplesFewer examplesIt's important that people accused of wobbler offenses have the strongest possible criminal defense.A large number of offenses can be considered to be wobbler crimes, including assault, breaking and entering, or DUI/DWI.
